segment.source: Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello
segment.target: Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello

segment.source: Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello replaces passwords with strong two-factor authentication (2FA) by verifying existing credentials and by creating a device-specific credential that a biometric or PIN-based user gesture protects.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport and Windows Hello replaces passwords with strong two-factor authentication (2FA) by verifying existing credentials and by creating a device-specific credential that a biometric or PIN-based user gesture protects.

segment.source: This combination effectively replaces physical and virtual smart cards as well as reusable passwords for logon and access control.
segment.target: This combination effectively replaces physical and virtual smart cards as well as reusable passwords for logon and access control.

segment.source: Credential Locker
segment.target: Credential Locker

segment.source: Credential Locker is a convenient and secure way to store user credentials that your app uses to connect to services like media, social networking, and so on.
segment.target: Credential Locker is a convenient and secure way to store user credentials that your app uses to connect to services like media, social networking, and so on.

segment.source: You can store a user's userid and password in the Credential Locker, and then automatically log them on to services when they use your app.
segment.target: You can store a user's userid and password in the Credential Locker, and then automatically log them on to services when they use your app.

segment.source: Credentials stored in the Credential Locker automatically roam with a users's Microsoft Account.
segment.target: Credentials stored in the Credential Locker automatically roam with a users's Microsoft Account.

segment.source: Web authentication broker
segment.target: Web authentication broker

segment.source: Web authentication broker supports the OAuth and OpenID internet authentication protocols, so you can integrate your app with a web service that provides user authentication.
segment.target: Web authentication broker supports the OAuth and OpenID internet authentication protocols, so you can integrate your app with a web service that provides user authentication.

segment.source: This allows you to utilize user identity in your apps from services such as Facebook, Flickr, Google, and Twitter.
segment.target: This allows you to utilize user identity in your apps from services such as Facebook, Flickr, Google, and Twitter.

segment.source: You can also use the web authentication broker to enable single sign-on (SSO) for multiple internet authenticated apps.
segment.target: You can also use the web authentication broker to enable single sign-on (SSO) for multiple internet authenticated apps.

segment.source: Fingerprint biometrics
segment.target: Fingerprint biometrics

segment.source: Including a request for fingerprint authentication when the user must consent to a particular action increases the security of your app.
segment.target: Including a request for fingerprint authentication when the user must consent to a particular action increases the security of your app.

segment.source: For example, you could require fingerprint authentication before authorizing an in-app purchase, or access to restricted resources.
segment.target: For example, you could require fingerprint authentication before authorizing an in-app purchase, or access to restricted resources.

segment.source: Fingerprint authentication is managed using the UserConsentVerifier class in the Windows.Security.Credentials.UI namespace.
segment.target: Fingerprint authentication is managed using the UserConsentVerifier class in the Windows.Security.Credentials.UI namespace.

segment.source: Smart cards
segment.target: Smart cards

segment.source: Smart cards and virtual smart cards provide a high level of authentication for your app.
segment.target: Smart cards and virtual smart cards provide a high level of authentication for your app.

segment.source: You can use the APIs in the Windows.Devices.SmartCards namespace to authenticate a user using a smart card, gather information about smart card devices, and manage smart card devices, such as requesting a PIN reset.
segment.target: You can use the APIs in the Windows.Devices.SmartCards namespace to authenticate a user using a smart card, gather information about smart card devices, and manage smart card devices, such as requesting a PIN reset.

segment.source: You can also create Trusted Platform Module (TPM) Virtual Smart Cards that provide smart card-level authentication without requiring a physical smart card from your user.
segment.target: You can also create Trusted Platform Module (TPM) Virtual Smart Cards that provide smart card-level authentication without requiring a physical smart card from your user.

segment.source: Shared certificates
segment.target: Shared certificates

segment.source: Certificate authentication provides a high level of trust when authenticating a user.
segment.target: Certificate authentication provides a high level of trust when authenticating a user.

segment.source: Apps that require secure authentication beyond a userid and password combination can use certificates for authentication.
segment.target: Apps that require secure authentication beyond a userid and password combination can use certificates for authentication.
